text:
It is no secret that Croatia is one of our
favourite countries to travel in Europe, and
Split is a destination that can’t be missed.

Set in and around the walls of an ancient
Roman palace looking out to the Adriatic Sea,

Split is what travel dreams are made of: sunny,
scenic, and filled with plenty of historic
sights and culinary delights to keep you busy.

The streets are a marble maze where pieces
of history lay hidden around every corner,

the harbour is lined with cafes and palm trees
drawing out locals and visitors to promenade

in the sunshine, and let’s not forget about
the abundance of restaurants serving up fresh

seafood and Croatian dishes with a contemporary
twist!

So join us in this travel guide as we take
you on a tour of the city and show you 15
things to do in Split, Croatia!

Okay so we are going to kick off our tour
of Split but first we need to show you how
close we are to the Diocletian Palace.
it is ridiculous.
We're on our street right now.

a bit we're going to turn.
Turn to the left.
Turn to the left just a bit.
A few more footsteps.
Yep.
And wait for it.
We're going to turn for the left.
Wait for it.
Turn turn tada.

It is right there.
Like could that be any more central.
Haha.

Diocletian was a Roman Emperor who ruled from
the years 284 to 305.

He was born in Dalmatia, and when it came
time to build his retirement residence, he

chose this very spot which today forms the
Old Town of Split.

It only made sense to start our tour of Split
here.

First, the bell tower for a quick look at
the city from above.
(Bells ringing)

So first up we are going to visit the Bell
Tower (Katedrala Svetog Duje).
That was 20 Kuna.

We also paid an extra 25 Kuna for another
ticket that is going to give us access to

the Mausoleum, the Crypt, the Temple of Jupiter
(Jupiterov hram).

and my feet wouldn’t budge, so the views
you’re seeing are all thanks to Sam.

Right next to the bell tower, you have the
Mausoleum of Diocletian.

Emperor Diocletian was a persecutor of Christians,
and ironically, his mausoleum is now a cathedral

named after Saint Domnius, who was martyred
by Diocletian.

Consecrated at the turn of the 7th century
AD, this is regarded as the oldest Catholic
cathedral in the world.

Keep in mind that because this is an active
place of worship, there are certain times
of day when it’s closed to visitors.

From there, we walked over to the Temple of
Jupiter.

Interesting fact: the sphinx you see at the
entrance was one of the twelve sphinxes brought
from Egypt by Emperor Diocletian.

Okay so right now we are in the Temple of
Jupiter.

Dedicated to the Ancient Roman God of Sky,

of Saint John the Baptist.

victim of the religious persecutions under
the rule of Diocletian.

While we were in the neighbourhood, we also
walked up the Marjan Steps for scenic views
of Split.

Marjan Hill is 178 meters high and it takes
314 steps to reach the highest point.

It’s a very pleasant walk with lots of greenery,
and along the way we even came across an old
stone church.

Well well what do you think of this little
hike so far?
It has been so much better than I had anticipated.
Like I thought the path would be shorter.

I also thought there wouldn't be as many good
lookout points.
There has been some amazing ones.
Yeah.

And also there has been some interesting look

Then on the way back down the hill, we went
for a walk through Varoš.

So another really cool area to visit here
in Split is the neighborhood of Varoš.

This is one of the oldest parts of the city
and it is where a lot of the fishermen used
to live.

So you get all of these cute little stone
houses with colorful shutters.
Colorful doors.
And it is super peaceful in this area.
Super quiet.

And while we were in Split, we also made time
to visit a statue with a rather famous toe.
This is Grgur Ninski.

He was a medieval Croatian bishop who introduced
the national language in the religious services,

at a time when services were only held in
Latin and could not be understood by most
of the population.

And now a travel tip: while you’re out strolling
down the Rive Promenade, you can also access

Matejuška Port, which is a harbour for small
boats used mainly by the local fishermen.

This particular spot offers some really nice
views looking back on Split.

Not too far from here, you also have the Green
Market, which is a great little spot to do
a bit of grocery shopping.
Alright alright.

And that’s a wrap for our travel guide to
Split!

We hope you guys enjoyed tagging along and
exploring this historic coastal city with
us.

As always, if you have any other ideas of
things to do in Split that you’d like to

share with travellers, feel free to share
those in the comments below.

In the meantime, wishing you happy travels,
and we’ll see you in the next video where
we continue our travels in Croatia.
